Graphical abstract Nickel-containing silica catalysts (Ni-SiO2) were synthetized via two methods: i) a modified direct synthesis and ii) incipient impregnation (as a control). The catalytic activity and deactivation of the products were evaluated in the dry reforming of methane (DRM). The modified direct synthesis method was found to favour the formation of Ni-phyllosilicates; these compounds led to a high Ni dispersion in the catalysts (even with 15 wt% of Ni). At short times of reaction, these catalysts showed low carbon deposition in comparison with that of the catalysts that were synthetized via the incipient impregnation method, which produced large carbon deposits. At long times on stream, the catalysts that contained Ni-phyllosilicates showed a severe sintering of the Ni particles during the DRM reaction at 700 °C. If the reactor is not operated in the kinetic regime, the activity loss is not adequately observed, even if significant sintering of Ni has already occurred in the catalyst. With the reactor operating in the kinetic regime, the deactivation curves can be fit using the deactivation model with residual activity (DMRA), and the Ni-SiO2 catalysts followed a second-order deactivation that was caused by the Ni sintering. Finally, at short times of reaction and with the reactor operating in the kinetic regime at 700 °C, an apparent activation energy of 80.3 kJ/mole was determined for the DRM reaction. Keywords Dry reforming of methane Deactivation Carbon deposition Ni-phyllosilicates Sintering 1 Introduction The emission of greenhouse gases that is due to the combustion of fossil fuels has become an important concern because of the damage that it causes to the environment (e.g., acid rain and global warming). The reuse of some of these gases in anthropogenic processes could contribute to the mitigation of the harmful effects of their accumulation in the atmosphere. Among the main pollutant gases, CH4 and CO2 contribute significantly to the greenhouse effect, and both are produced in large amounts in anthropogenic processes. Instead, these two compounds could be used in the dry reforming of methane (DRM) reaction to produce synthesis gas (CO + H2), which could be used as feedstock in several reactions (for example, methanol synthesis and the production of liquid fuels via the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis (FTS) reaction [1,2]. Currently, the steam reforming of methane is the preferred industrial process for the production of synthesis gas; nevertheless, DRM could be an ecological option because it does not use water as a reactant. Therefore, this process could be ideal in places where water resources are limited and could use the byproduct gases of anthropogenic processes (e.g., CO2 from combustion processes and CH4 from farm animals). However, despite the environmental benefits of this reaction, its use in industry is rare because there are parallel reactions, such as the Boudouard reaction (2CO(g) → C(s) + CO2(g)) and methane decomposition (CH4(g) → C(s) + 2H2(g)), that occur simultaneously and produce carbon deposits; this causes the deactivation of the catalysts and, eventually, could clog the reactor [3]. This drawback is the main reason for steam reforming being the preferred reaction for synthesis gas production, as the deactivation of the catalysts is less severe because there is only one source of carbon atoms [4]. It is necessary to develop a catalyst with a high activity and selectivity for the DRM reaction that can operate for a long time. The catalyst should have a low promotion of carbon formation and a high resistance to the oxidation and sintering of active sites. The chemical elements of group VIII (transition metals) show activity for the DRM reaction in their elemental states [1,4–6]. For instance, Ferreira-Aparicio et al. [5] reported a study of Co, Ni, Ru, Rh, Ir and Pt that were supported on γ-Al2O3 and SiO2. The authors found that at 750 °C, the Rh, Ru and Ni catalysts showed high activities, among which the Rh and Ru metals yielded low carbon depositions and, therefore, low deactivation rates. However, both Rh and Ru are expensive, and their availability is limited; thus, their implementation on the industrial scale is not feasible. This is the main reason that the efforts in the development of catalysts for the DRM reaction have been focused on Ni as the active component [7], as it is more abundant than Rh and Ru in the earth and is less expensive. γ-Al2O3 has been frequently used as a support, which is due mostly to its thermal stability and its satisfactory distribution of Ni that is supported on its surface, thereby resulting in high activity of the catalyst. However, this support has the disadvantages that the acid sites on its surface (Brønsted and Lewis) catalyse CH4 and CO2 decompositions and both reactions produce carbon deposits on the catalyst. Additionally, at high temperatures, the strong interaction of Ni with this support forms an inactive species of nickel aluminate (NiAl2O4) [8]. SiO2 has a low surface acidity; thus, as a support, it promotes a low rate of carbon deposition. However, the structures that this oxide form hinder the metal dispersion on its surface, thereby requiring the use of alternative methods for the catalyst’s synthesis to overcome this issue [9]. If the drawback of Ni dispersion is overcome, a Ni-based catalyst that uses SiO2 as a support could be a satisfactory option for the DRM reaction. For example, Chen et al. [10] reported that a satisfactory Ni distribution was realized at low metal loadings (∼ 5 wt%) via the use of hexagonal mesoporous silica (HMS) and suggested that the sintering of Ni was restricted due to a stronger interaction between the Ni and the HMS support. Zhang et al. [11] tested several Ni-based catalysts with various supports and found that SiO2, TiO2 and ZrO2 supports showed weak interaction with NiO, which could lead to the agglomeration of Ni and, hence, to the deactivation of the catalysts. With Al2O3 and MgO supports, the authors observed a strong interaction with NiO, which suggests that the use of these supports could prevent the sintering of Ni via the formation of a spinel or a solid solution, respectively. Similar results were reported by Wang et al. [12] for nickel that was supported on Al2O3, SiO2 and MgO; the authors suggested that a strong interaction between the active metal and the support led to a higher resistance against metal sintering and carbon formation. In both cases, researchers attributed the enhanced resistance to the formation of Ni species such as Ni-silicates and Ni-aluminates during the synthesis of the catalysts; however, the calcination and activation of the catalysts occurred at T ≤ 500 °C, which could prevent the complete evolution or segregation of these species. It was reported that using the “direct synthesis” method can produce a catalyst with 7 wt% of Ni on HMS. At higher loadings, the structure of HMS was no longer obtained, and the solid became thermally unstable, while the catalysts resulted in approximately the same Ni content (∼7 wt%), even when a load of 20 wt% of Ni in the catalyst was intended (nominal loading) [10]. However, this synthetic method has the advantage that at low metal loadings, the formed Ni clusters are small compared with those that are obtained via the incipient wetness method. The drawback of the “direct synthesis” method may be overcome via a prior modification of the support precursor. For example, Wang et al. [13] obtained a catalyst with 14.7 wt% of Ni on MCM-41 with a previous modification of the Ni precursor. The modification consisted of the reaction of nickel nitrate with ethylene glycol for the production of a cyclic nickel glycoxide; this species reacted subsequently with tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) to produce (C2H5O)3Si-O-Ni-O-Si-(C2H5O)3 [14]. It was suggested that a homogeneous dispersion of Ni in the MCM-41 structure was possible because the co-condensation and co-hydrolysis occur at the molecular level during the interaction between Ni ions and the TEOS. Furthermore, Wang et al. [13,14] found that the use of this method promoted the formation of Ni-phyllosilicates (PSs). Additionally, the authors observed that most of the Ni was incorporated into the mesostructure, and a small fraction was segregated as bulk NiO. Sivaiah et al. [15] reported the DRM reaction with Ni-phyllosilicates as the catalysts. The researchers found that the 2:1 phyllosilicate showed a catalytic activity and stability that were higher than those of the 1:1 phyllosilicate. This result was attributed to less sintering of Ni0 due to reduced metal-metal interactions and to the small size of the metallic particles (< 15 nm). Thus, the use of Ni and SiO2 as a support, or a mixture of SiO2 and Ni-phyllosilicates, seems to be a satisfactory alternative for obtaining a catalyst for the DRM reaction with a low deactivation rate if high dispersion of the metal in the catalyst can be realized. The objective of this work is to study the activity and deactivation of Ni-SiO2 catalysts that are synthetized via a modified “direct synthesis” method and to compare the catalytic performances of these solids with those of catalysts that are synthetized via the incipient impregnation method. The understanding of the catalyst deactivation could lead to improvements in the resistance of the catalysts against sintering and carbon deposition during the reaction in the DRM process. 2 Experimentation 2.1 Synthesis of the catalyst The SiO2 support was synthesized via the following method: a mixture of tetraethyl orthosilicate (SiO4(C2H5)4, Sigma-Aldrich) and ethanol was prepared, and a second mixture of dodecylamine (CH3 (CH2)15NH2, Sigma Aldrich), ethanol and deionized water (with C2H5OH/H2O = 8.5 v/v) was added to the first mixture under vigorous stirring. The resultant solution was stirred 24 h at room temperature. Then, the formed solid was filtered and washed initially with ethanol and subsequently with deionized water. The powder was dried at room temperature for 24 h and calcined at 550 °C in static air for 6 h to remove the organic template. To promote the satisfactory dispersion of Ni in the catalyst, a variant of the “direct synthesis” method that was proposed by Wang et al. [13,14] was used. Briefly, 20 ml of ethylene glycol (Sigma Aldrich) and the required amount of Ni(NO3)2 (Sigma Aldrich) were mixed in a beaker under stirring at 80 °C for 10 h. Then, tetraethyl orthosilicate (TEOS) was added to this mixture, and the resultant solution was allowed to react for 10 h. Finally, “Ni-modified TEOS” and an organic phase that was composed of diethyl-ether and ethanol were obtained. The “Ni-modified TEOS” was separated and added to the dodecylamine and ethanol/water solution, which was described above. The obtained catalysts were labelled mX (X = wt% nominal content of Ni). For comparison with the mX catalysts in terms of catalytic performance, a series of catalysts were prepared via the incipient wetness method with the synthetized SiO2 as a support and solutions of the Ni nitrate salt. These catalysts were labelled iX (X = wt% nominal content of Ni). All synthetized catalysts were dried at 100 °C for 4 h and calcined at 550 °C in static air for 4 h. 2.2 Catalytic activity The DRM reaction was conducted in a tubular quartz microreactor (ɸ =11 mm). The gases were fed into the reactor using electronic mass flow controllers (Aalborg). The reactor feed consisted of equimolar amounts of CH4 and CO2 in He balance (CH4:CO2:He, 1:1:1). All gases were supplied by INFRA, and CO2 of industrial grade was used to establish a reaction environment that was similar to practical conditions. The CO2 was fed into the reaction stream without further treatment. The total flow rate through the reactor was 70 cm3/min, and the mass of catalyst that was loaded in the reactor was 20 mg. Prior to the catalytic test, the catalysts were reduced in situ at 700 °C for 1 h using a flow rate of 30 cm3/min for a mixture of 5 % H2 in N2 balance. For the catalytic activity tests, the temperature was varied from 400 to 900 °C; the higher reaction temperature was used to evaluate the catalytic performances of the solids above the calcination and activation temperatures of the catalysts (to evaluate their stabilities under thermal stress). The deactivation tests were conducted at 700 °C under the conditions of the kinetic regime (the SiO2 support was used as a diluent to maintain a constant contact time). The reactants and the reactor effluent were analysed online using a gas chromatograph (Shimadzu, GC-15A) that was equipped with a thermal conductivity detector and a Porapak-N packed column. 2.3 Characterization The compositions of the catalysts were measured via atomic absorption spectrometry (Varian, 220FS SpectrAA). The X-ray diffraction (XRD) technique (Siemens d-5000) was used to measure the NiO crystallite size via the Scherrer equation. The FT-IR spectra (IR Affinity, Shimadzu) were used to identify the interactions of Ni with the support, and a UV–vis spectrometer (Varian, Cary 5E) that was equipped with a diffuse reflectance accessory (Praying Mantis, Harrick) was used to identify the differences in the Ni oxide on the catalysts. To determine the specific surface areas of the catalysts, the N2 physisorption technique (ASAP 2020, Micrometrics Instruments) was used. H2-TPR experiments (homemade equipment) were conducted to evaluate the differences in reducibility among the mX an iX catalysts. A sample of 30 mg of catalyst was used, and prior to loading it into the reactor, it was ground in an agate mortar. For the iX catalysts, the temperature of the reactor was raised from room temperature to 700 °C using a heating ramp of 10 °C/min. For the mX catalysts, a similar procedure to that in the catalyst activation was followed: i) the temperature of the reactor was raised from room temperature to 700 °C using a heating ramp of 10 °C/min, ii) the temperature of the reactor was maintained at 700 °C for 1 h, and iii) the reactor temperature was raised from 700 to 1000 °C using a heating ramp of 10 °C/min. In all cases, a mixture of 10 % of H2 in Ar balance was flowed through the reactor at a rate of 25 cm3/min. Transmission electron microscopy (FEI TITAN G2 80–300) at 300 KeV was used to observe the differences in the distribution and morphologies of the Ni particles in the mX catalysts. Scanning electron microscopy (FEI Nova NanoSEM 200) and Raman spectroscopy (Thermo Scientific DXR Raman Microscope with a 532-nm laser) were used to reveal and identify the type of carbon that was deposited on the catalyst surface. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Ni content and characterization of fresh catalysts via XRD In Table 1 , the Ni contents of the mX and iX catalysts are listed. The Ni contents were similar to the nominal contents. The low Ni contents that were used for the iX series, in comparison to those of their mX counterparts, were chosen to facilitate comparison of catalytic activities among both types of catalysts; this will be discussed further with the reaction results. It has been reported that various crystalline species of Ni, such as NiO, Ni(OH)2 and Ni-silicates, can coexist in the Ni-SiO2 system [16,17]. In Fig. 1 A, the XRD patterns for the iX catalysts are shown. A broad peak that is centred at 2θ = 22° is observed and is characteristic of amorphous SiO2 supports [10,18]. Three peaks are assigned to NiO, which are centred at 2θ = 37.3, 43 and 63° and correspond to the (100), (200) and (220) planes, respectively [10]. In Fig. 1B, the patterns of the mX catalysts are shown, where two small and broad peaks can be observed next to the main SiO2 amorphous peak. It has been reported that Ni-silicates show peaks at 2θ = 35 and 60° [19]. Therefore, it is likely that the small peaks result from the convolution of NiO and Ni-silicates peaks. In this case, it was not possible to identify the type of silicate that formed because the characteristic peaks of the silicates are overlapped with the amorphous peak of the SiO2; however, this peak becomes broader as the Ni loading increases, thereby suggesting the presence of Ni-silicates. The XRD patterns in Fig. 1 indicate that the use of the modified “direct synthesis” method could be sufficient for obtaining satisfactory dispersion of large amounts of Ni on the support. In Table 2 , the sizes of the crystallites that are estimated using the Scherrer equation are listed. The sizes of the NiO particles in the mX catalysts are substantially smaller (see also the TEM image in Figure S4, which was obtained prior to the DRM reaction) than those that were obtained for the reference iX catalysts, which accords with the reports in the literature [10]. 3.2 N2 physisorption Figure S1 shows the N2-physisorption isotherms for the parent SiO2 support and those that correspond to the i10 and m15 catalysts. The m15 catalyst shows type IV (IUPAC) isotherms, which are typical of mesoporous solids, whereas the isotherms for the SiO2 and i10 solids correspond to type II (IUPAC). The textural properties of both types of catalysts are listed in Table 1. For the iX catalysts, the specific surface area decreases as the Ni loading increases, and this results in the blockage of the small pores of the support by NiO particles with sizes that exceed the pore size [20]. For the mX catalysts, the incorporation of Ni during the catalyst synthesis has an important effect on the textural properties because the specific surface area increases with the Ni loading, and a difference of ∼13 % is observed between the specific surface areas of the m15 and m05 catalysts. This effect suggests the presence of Ni-phyllosilicates because the lamellar structure of these compounds could make an important contribution to the increase in the specific surface area. 3.3 IR characterization In Fig. 2 , the FTIR spectra of the SiO2 support and the mX catalysts are shown. A blueshift from 460 to 470 cm−1 is observed in the band that is attributed to the Si-O-Si stretching vibration as the Ni loading in the catalyst increases. This shift suggests that an interaction occurs between the Ni and the silica matrix [13]. Furthermore, the m05 and m15 catalysts show small bands (a doublet) at 667 and 704 cm−1, which have been assigned to the tetrahedral SiO mode and the δOH vibration of the isolated OH that is surrounded by three Ni atoms, respectively [21]. The surface silanol groups (962 cm−1) are involved in the interaction between the support and the Ni that is loaded in the catalysts [16], and this band decreases and disappears with the increase of the Ni loading in the catalysts. This result suggests that Ni species are well distributed on the support since the silanol groups are randomly located on the support. It has been reported that the synthetic method that is used for the silica-based catalysts induces the formation of layered Ni silicates (Ni-phyllosilicates) [13]. Additionally, the 2:1 (Ni3(Si4O10)(OH)2) and 1:1 (Ni3(Si2O5)(OH)4) Ni-phyllosilicates [15,21] show a single band and a doublet, respectively, between 600−700 cm−1 [15]; however, from the spectra in Fig. 2, such a distinction is not possible because the bands are overlapped. Fig. 3 shows the spectra that were obtained during in situ reduction of the mX catalysts. Two bands are observed: one at 3733 cm−1, which is assigned to the Si−OH stretching vibration [22], and another at 3618 cm−1, which intensifies with the Ni loading in the catalyst. The band at 3618 cm−1 has been associated with the presence of 1:1 Ni-phyllosilicate [16]; however, the disappearance of this band at high temperatures (> 550 °C) suggests the presence of the 2:1 Ni-phyllosilicate. 3.4 UV–vis characterization UV-vis characterization was used to examine the differences among the Ni oxide species on the iX and mX catalysts. Fig. 4 A shows the spectra of the iX catalysts and bulk NiO, which is used as a reference obtained from the calcination of Ni-nitrate salt. Two broad bands are observed, namely, one that is centred at approximately 33,664 cm−1 and a weak band at 13,654 cm−1, which are both assigned to Ni2+ ions in the NiO-type phase [23]. The former band intensifies with increasing Ni loading in the catalysts. As a reference, the spectrum of NiO is also shown in Fig. 4A. The spectra of the iX catalysts show approximately the same bands that correspond to NiO, which is expected due to the method that is used for the synthesis of these catalysts (incipient impregnation). Fig. 4B shows the spectra of the mX catalysts, and the bands that are centred at 45,370 and 42,508 cm−1 are assigned to charge transfer transitions. The band at 37,807 cm−1 is assigned to Ni2+ ions in the NiO-type phase with a different size and shape [24], whereas the bands at 24290, 14,737 and 13,395 cm−1 are assigned to Ni2+ in a distorted octahedral coordination [23,25]. The presence of the charge transition bands in these catalysts suggests the presence of Ni-phyllosilicates and NiO nanoparticles [24]. 3.5 H2-TPR characterization In Fig. 5 A, the reduction profiles of the iX catalysts are shown, and the three catalysts clearly exhibit a broad peak between 300–600 °C, which is assigned to the NiO → Ni° reduction. In all cases, there is a peak tailing that suggests the presence of large NiO particles (see Table 2), which result in slow H2 diffusion during the reduction reaction [26]. The reduction profiles of the mX catalysts (Fig. 5B) differ from those that were obtained for the iX catalysts. For these catalysts, four peaks were observed. The first peak, namely, the peak at approximately 396 °C, is assigned to the reduction of bulk NiO, and in all catalysts, it is smaller than the observed peak for the iX catalysts. The second peak, namely, the peak at 462 °C, is assigned to the reduction of the terminal sites of Ni [16] that are formed during the synthesis of the catalysts, whereas the peaks at 566 and 667 °C are assigned to the reductions of Ni-phyllosilicates 1:1 and 2:1, respectively [15]. According to Fig. 5A, all the NiO that was present in the iX catalysts was reduced below 700 °C. For the mX catalysts, according to Fig. 5B, when the reactor reached 700 °C (during the TPR experiment), not all the Ni-species were completely reduced (this is more evident for the m15 catalyst); however, during the time that the reactor was maintained at 700 °C (in this case, 1 h), all the Ni-species were completely reduced. The broad peak that appeared when the reactor temperature was raised from 700 to 1000 °C was for the three catalysts and corresponded to less than 1 % of the total area. These results demonstrate that for both the iX and mX catalysts, essentially all the Ni that was present could be in metallic form after the activation treatment was conducted at 700 °C. 3.6 Catalytic activity evaluation For comparison, the thermodynamic equilibrium curves were calculated via the Gibbs free energy minimization method for the dry reforming of methane (CH4 + CO2 ↔ 2CO + 2H2) and the inverse of the water gas shift (CO2 + H2 ↔ CO + H2O). The objective of this comparison is to compare the catalysts’ performances with that of the ideal case in which carbon deposits are not formed. The catalytic tests for the iX catalysts had to be divided into two temperature ranges because the carbon formation clogged the gas flow through the reactor. This was the reason behind the incorporation of less Ni in these catalysts than in the mX catalysts. The first range was from 400 to 600 °C, and the second was from 700 to 900 °C. Fresh catalysts were used for each temperature range of the catalytic tests; this is in agreement with reports in the literature that the incipient impregnation method results in poor catalytic performances of Ni-based catalysts for the DRM reaction [27]. The CH4 conversion for the iX catalysts versus the reactor temperature is plotted in Fig. 6 A; the thermodynamic curve is included for comparison of the experimental conversions with the theoretical equilibrium prediction. The CH4 conversion values that were obtained with the i08 and i10 catalysts at 500 and 600 °C are larger than the theoretical prediction. Additionally, the i08 catalyst shows a higher conversion than that of the i10 catalyst, which is presumably because the latter could form carbonaceous deposits faster, thereby resulting in lower conversion. The CH4 conversion of the i03 catalyst never exceeds the equilibrium curve and reaches the equilibrium conversion only at 900 °C. Nikoo et al. [28] conducted a thermodynamic analysis of the DRM reaction, which included the formation of solid carbon via the Boudouard and CH4 decomposition reactions. The authors found that the production of solid carbon is favoured from 300 to 700 °C and decreases drastically at higher temperatures. Therefore, the high potential for the formation of solid carbon at T < 700 °C could explain the rapid blockage of the gas flow in the reactor as the formation of carbon deposits on these catalysts increases. For the mX catalysts, it was not necessary to replace the catalyst in the reactor during the catalytic test because these catalysts form less carbon during the reaction. These catalysts show a CH4 conversion curve that is similar to the trend of the equilibrium curve over the entire tested temperature range (Fig. 6B); however, for the m5 and m10 catalysts, the observed conversions are lower than those at thermodynamic equilibrium, which is presumably due to the small number of active sites in comparison with the m15 catalyst. The carbon deposition on the catalyst is directly associated with the numbers of carbon atoms (in this case, from CH4 and CO2) at the inlet and at the outlet of the reactor. Thus, the yields of CO and H2 (Eq. 1 and Eq. 2, respectively) were calculated, and the values are useful for visualizing the carbon atoms in the feed that are effectively transformed into the desired gaseous compounds. (1) C O y i e l d ( % ) = n C O n C H 4 + n C O 2 f e e d x 100 (2) H 2 y i e l d ( % ) = 2 n H 2 4 ( n C H 4 ) f e e d x 100 Fig. 7 plots the CO and H2 yields versus the reactor temperature for the iX catalysts (Figs. 7A and 7B, respectively). The CO yield is low compared with that at thermodynamic equilibrium, mainly at T > 600 °C, while the H2 yield seems to follow the equilibrium curve, mainly for the i08 and i10 catalysts. However, large values of the H2/CO ratio (Figure 7C) are observed at T < 700 °C, which indicates the decomposition of CH4 and seems to be the most prevalent reason for carbon deposition in the temperature range of 400–700 °C [29]. Additionally, at T ≥ 700 °C, the CO yield does not reach the equilibrium curve, and the H2/CO ratio is above of the equilibrium curve; these two factors suggest that the CO disproportionation reaction is occurring and is the main contributor to carbon deposition at higher temperatures [30,31]. It is expected that the use of the modified “direct synthesis” method will lead to superior dispersion of the Ni due to its binding with the TEOS precursor during the synthesis of the catalysts [13] and, hence, lead to a decrease in the rate of carbon formation during the DRM reaction. According to Fig. 8 , all the mX catalysts show similar CO and H2 yields (Figs. 8A and 8B) over the entire tested temperature range, which could be related to the small size of the Ni sites in these catalysts [32]. In addition, the H2/CO ratios are close (in contrast to the iX catalysts) to the thermodynamic equilibrium curve, even in the temperature range of 400–600 °C, in which carbon deposition is thermodynamically favoured. At high temperatures (T ≥ 800 °C), for both the iX and mX catalysts, the same value of H2/CO ∼1.2 is observed (Figs. 7C and 8C, respectively), which is larger than the ratio that is predicted by the thermodynamic equilibrium. The last observation is a result of the loss of the structure due to the high reaction temperature in comparison with that used in the calcination of the catalysts. According to the TGA characterization (Figure S2-A and S2-B), the i08 and m10 catalysts lose 42 and 32 wt%, respectively, at 700 °C and totals of 71 and 60 wt%, respectively, at 900 °C. Thus, it is expected that at T ≥ 800 °C, the Ni sites will have almost the same catalytic performance due to the sintering of Ni on both solids, which is due to structural collapse, in the case of the mX catalysts (see Figure S2-C). The likely cause for the smaller weight loss of the m10 catalyst compared to that of the i08 catalyst is the large amount of Ni-phyllosilicates in the former. According to the TPR profiles of the mX catalysts (Fig. 5B), the 2:1 Ni-phyllosilicate is reduced at approximately 670 °C; thus, a structural collapse that is caused by a complete reduction is expected. According to Figs. 6 and 8, the m10 and m15 catalysts have similar catalytic performances and realize satisfactory CH4 conversions. These two catalysts were tested at 700 °C to evaluate their resistance against deactivation as function of the time on stream (TOS), and the results are presented in Fig. 9 . Both catalysts showed satisfactory stability during the deactivation test, and the CO2 conversion (Fig. 9B) is slightly higher than CH4 conversion (Fig. 9A) for both catalysts. This suggests that the main reactions that occur on the catalysts are the dry reforming of methane and the inverse of the water gas shift. However, the H2/CO ratio (Fig. 9C) is larger than the predicted value by the thermodynamic equilibrium; hence, there is more H2, which is presumably due to the methane decomposition reaction (CH4 → C(s) + H2). Therefore, it is expected that the solid carbon that is formed will be deposited and, eventually, will deactivate the catalysts. 3.7 Characterization of the catalysts after the DRM reaction The characterizations that were obtained via scanning electron microscopy (SEM) and Raman spectroscopy of the catalysts that were used in the reaction tests are presented in Fig. 6. For the iX catalysts, the micrographs show the formation of filaments of carbon (Figures S3-A, -B and -C), whereas for the mX catalysts, there was no evidence of filament formation (Figures S3-D, -E, and -F). The characterization of the iX catalysts via Raman spectroscopy shows the D (1337 cm−1) and the G (1570 cm−1) bands (Fig. 10 A), which are assigned to disordered and crystalline graphite [33], whereas for the mX catalysts, two incipient peaks are observed only for the m10 catalyst (Fig. 10B). For the i03 catalyst, the D band exhibits a higher intensity than in the i08 and i10 catalysts. This result suggests higher disorder in the carbonaceous structure [34], which is likely because in this catalyst, the active sites are further separated from each other. In Fig. 11 A, the XRD patterns are shown for the mX catalysts after the reaction test at 700 °C for 1450 min under the DRM reaction. The size of the Ni particles increased substantially during the deactivation test and reached an average size of 15 nm (calculated from XRD; see Table 2). Additionally, in the patterns, peaks that are assigned to the carbon that is deposited on the catalysts are observed. The catalysts were not passivated before they were removed from the reactor; hence, there are also NiO present in the catalysts at the moment of the XRD measurements, which could cause an error in the estimation of the crystallite size, thereby often leading to low sizes [35]. To confirm the sizes of Ni particles in the spent catalysts, they were characterized via transmission electron microscopy (TEM). In Fig. 11B, a TEM image is shown of the m15 catalyst after the reaction, where the Ni particles reached sizes of larger than 20 nm. The Ni particle sizes that were observed for the m05 and m15 catalysts that were tested in the DRM reaction, which are presented in Fig. 9, seems to be in the same range (see Figure S4 after 1450 min during the DRM reaction), which suggests that metal loading was not a significant parameter in the sintering process and that this occurred rapidly, thereby leading to a limit on the Ni particle size, which was approximately 30 nm in this case. The sintered Ni particles that are shown in the TEM image of Fig. 11B do not have a “spherical” shape, thereby suggesting that there was an additional effect in the sintering of the Ni particles during the DRM reaction, which was likely due to an impurity from the CO2 that was used (industrial grade). It has been reported that this shape could result from the sintering of Ni particles in presence of sulfur in the gas atmosphere, which causes a distortion of the crystal structure, thereby promoting the self-diffusion of Ni [36]. It is plausible that this compound was present (as an impurity) in the reaction stream. The supplier of the CO2 has no information about the impurities in this product, and during the reaction tests, no other compounds were detected. Moreover, it was not possible to characterize the catalysts via energy dispersive X-ray spectrometry due to experimental restrictions. Thus, we cannot determine whether the presence of sulfur was the reason for the shape of the sintered Ni particles. The sintering of Ni particles has been studied in the literature under steam reforming conditions (in a non-reactive atmosphere). For example, Sehested et al. [35] reported that at 500 °C and 30 bar, the sintering of Ni particles reached a limit size (between 27 and 37 nm) in a model catalyst that was composed of Ni that was supported on a Zr-doped spinel. The authors showed that only the presence of steam (and high total pressures) had a significant effect on the sintering of the Ni particles. Moreover, both the metal loading and the support texture weakly influence the sintering process. In another study, Sehested et al. [37] reported that at 700 °C and 1 bar, the Ostwald ripening mechanism could explain the sintering of Ni particles, whereas below this temperature, the coalescence-driven sintering is the predominant mechanism. From the results that are presented in Fig. 9, it is inferred that if there were impurities in the reaction stream, such as sulfur, the sintering rate could be higher due to the promotion of these impurities over the migration of Ni atoms, thereby resulting in a higher sintering rate of the Ni particles. In Fig. 9, no decay in the activity (deactivation) is observed, even when the H2/CO ratio evidence the formation of carbon, which suggests that these curves could make important contributions to the mass transport that hides the deactivation of the catalysts. This could be the reason that in the literature, there are reports that show quasi-linear activity decay curves [11] or curves that decrease slowly prior to an abrupt decay [32]. Thus, it is necessary to operate the reactor in kinetic regime conditions to observe the true deactivation curves of the catalysts. 3.8 Kinetic conditions The next part of the study was conducted at 700 °C because at this temperature, a 75 % CH4 conversion and a CO yield of approximately 60 % are realized (Figs. 6B and 8A). The operation of the reactor at this temperature could yield a large savings of energy in an industrial-scale implementation. Prior to the measurement of the deactivation curves of the catalysts, several tests were conducted to guarantee that the reactor operated in the kinetic regimen (to minimize the external resistance to mass transfer [38]). The internal resistance to mass transfer was neglected because the particle sizes of the catalysts were smaller than 100 μm, and, additionally, the samples were ground in an agate mortar prior to being loaded into the reactor. The m10 catalyst was chosen for these deactivation tests because it showed satisfactory catalytic performance for the DRM reaction (see Fig. 9), and on a commercial scale, the use of the smallest metal loading and a low temperature is necessary for making the DRM an environmentally friendly process [39]. To change the contact time (W/F) in the reactor, the catalyst weight was varied in the bed while maintaining the same operating conditions in the reactor for all the catalytic tests; this was realized by adding a diluent (in this case, the SiO2 support). Fig. 12 A plots the CH4 conversion versus the W/F ratio. From a contact time value of 4 × 10−5 gcat min cm−3, a constant conversion is realized; this result demonstrates that above this value, the external mass transfer influences the catalytic reaction, whereas below this value, the reactor can be regarded as operating in the kinetic regime. Based on these results, W/F = 2 × 10−5 gcat min cm−3 was used (this represents 1.4 mg of catalyst in the catalytic bed; under these reaction conditions, the conversion rate of CH4 was approximately 20 %). Under these operating conditions (kinetic regime, low temperatures, and short reaction times on stream), the apparent activation energy of the DMR reaction was determined (assuming a pseudo-first-order reaction rate for CH4). A value of 80.3 kJ/mol was obtained (Fig. 12B), which is of the same order of magnitude as that obtained by Olsbye et al. [40] for a Ni/La/Al2O3 catalyst (90 kJ/mol) and that reported by Xie et al. [41] for a Pt/ZrO2 catalyst (82 kJ/mol), and it is close to the values that were reported by Garcia et al. [42] for Ni-based catalysts (104–151 kJ/mol). However, in the literature, values from 29.3–359.8 kJ/mol for a variety of catalysts have often been reported [27,31,43,44]. It is proposed that in the mechanism of the DRM reaction, the CH4 and CO2 molecules each adsorb at separate active sites. The adsorbed CH4 releases one hydrogen atom, thereby forming an adsorbed radical (CH3*) [31,41,45], and this process is considered the fundamental step of the DRM reaction. As was reported [41], the theoretical activation energies that are calculated via density functional theory (DFT) were 70 and 84 kJ/mol for Pt(111) and mixed-PtCo(111), respectively, while Beebe et al. [46] reported experimental activation energies for CH4 decomposition of 52.7, 26.8 and 55.6 kJ/mol for Ni(111), Ni(100) and Ni(110), respectively. In both cases, the values of the activation energy are less than 100 kJ/mol, which suggests that the value that is determined in this work could be close to the intrinsic value of the DRM reaction. 3.9 Catalyst deactivation In Fig. 13 the experimental deactivation curves for the iX (Fig. 13A) and mX (Fig. 13B) catalysts during the DRM reaction at a constant temperature (700 °C) and under the kinetic regime are plotted. Both types of catalysts with high metal loadings show slow deactivation, which is either because they possess more potential active sites or because the Ni particles are more stable against sintering. For the mX catalysts, an increase in the measured activity is observed during the initial hours of the reaction, which suggests that there are rearrangements of the metal sites that form additional active sites in the catalysts [47]. The increase in activity is more marked for the catalyst with the highest metal loading (the m15 catalyst). This rearrangement could be promoted by either the presence of CO, as has been reported, or the interaction between Ni and CO, which induces the reconstruction of the metal on the catalytic surface [31], and rearrangements of Ni particles (during sintering) are induced by the reactive atmosphere and by impurities (e.g., sulfur) in the gas stream. According to the XRD and TEM characterizations of the catalysts that are shown in Fig. 9, the Ni sintering occurred rapidly and the Ni sintered particles reached a size that is close to the reported limit. For example, Guzi et al. [48] observed that Ni sintering particles after the DRM reaction (at 800 °C) reached a size that was between 26 and 35 nm, which accords with the range that was reported for Ni particle sintering by Sehested et al. [35]. Furthermore, according to Fig. 11B, the sintered Ni particles are enveloped by a carbon layer (Figure S5), and carbon filaments are present. Thus, the characterization results demonstrate that the main cause of deactivation of mX catalysts is prompted by the sintering of Ni particles and that these particles are subsequently enveloped by a carbon layer during the DRM reaction. The deactivation model with residual activity (DMRA) [49] was used to compare the deactivation rates and their influence factors among the catalysts. Eq. 3 expresses the general form that is proposed for this model. − d a d t = ψ d * P i , T a − a s ( P i , T ) d * where a represents the catalytic activity, t is the time, d* is the deactivation order, and ψ d * is a deactivation function that depends of the amount of the compound (Pi ) that induces the deactivation and the reactor temperature (T). The as term refers to the residual activity and depends on the same variables in the deactivation function. It is assumed that if the measurements of the catalytic activity are conducted under isothermal conditions while maintaining constant flow and composition, then ψ d * and as are constants [49] and can be easily determined. According to the results (Fig. 11B), two processes are occurring simultaneously (the sintering of the Ni particles and the carbon formation on the Ni sintered particles), and both finally result in the deactivation of the catalysts. Due to the rapid sintering of the Ni particles in the mX catalysts, the rate of carbon formation on the catalysts was assumed to be lower, and under these conditions, Eq. 3 could provide an approximate description of the catalyst deactivation process. In Tables 3 and 4 , the fitting parameters of the deactivation curves that are obtained using the first- and second-order equations of the DMRA for the iX and mX catalysts, respectively, are presented. According to the values in Table 3, the deactivation constant (ψ) increases with the metal loading in the iX catalysts, which accords with the rapid clogging of the gas flow in the reactor during streaming. For these catalysts, both deactivation orders fit the data well, although the residual activity (as) values for the second-order fits are in closest agreement with the expected physical behaviour, namely, a high Ni loading will be expected to promote a high residual activity due to the larger number of potential active sites. For the mX catalysts, the fit was obtained only for the m5 and m10 catalysts because the m15 catalyst showed initially (first 100 min) high variations, which were due to the metal migration. According to Table 4, the second-order fit more closely fit the deactivation curves for these catalysts and is much more congruent with the expected physical value for the residual activity. According to the fitting parameters in Tables 3 and 4, for the iX catalysts, the deactivation process seems to follow a different deactivation path than for the mX catalysts. For the iX catalysts, the carbon formation seems to be the essential cause of the activity decay; this is evidenced by the increase of the deactivation constant with the increase of the metal loading in the catalysts. This is consequence of the larger size of the Ni particles (Table 2) from the beginning of the deactivation tests. In contrast, for mX catalysts, the sintering of Ni particles is the most important contribution to the catalyst deactivation, and the deactivation constant is larger for the catalysts with lower metal loading (the m05 catalyst). A long-term reaction test (3000 min) with the m10 catalyst was conducted to determine the optimal deactivation order for fitting the deactivation curves of the mX catalysts; this catalyst was chosen because it showed satisfactory performance during the 240-min reaction test and had few active site modifications (see Fig. 13B). In Fig. 14 A, the activity decay vs time on stream at 700 °C is plotted. For comparison, in Fig. 14B, the curves that were reported by Sehested et al. [35] (normalizing the values using the maximum of each curve) are plotted, and the corresponding deactivation curve for the m10 catalyst was extrapolated using the fitting parameters of Table 4. It is assumed for this comparison that the sulfur capacity measurements can be associated directly to the active surface that is available for the DRM reaction and, hence, to the catalytic activity. All the curves in Fig. 14 were fitted using the DMRA equation in consideration of the first and second orders. The fitting parameters are listed in Table 4, and the second-order equation shows the best fit to the deactivation curve of the m10 catalyst. Moreover, the second deactivation order fits very closely the curves that were obtained by Sehested et al., which strongly suggests that the deactivation of the mX catalysts (caused by Ni sintering) can be rationalized by the parameters that are obtained by the DMRA model. It has been reported that the main factors that could affect the catalytic activity of the silica-based catalysts are the metal dispersion, the sizes of the active sites, and the morphology of the metal particles [31,43,50]. As discussed above, the use of the modified “direct method” for the synthesis of the mX catalysts promotes the formation of Ni-phyllosilicates, and it has been suggested that these species are less prone to carbon production because the metallic Ni particles are stabilized on a nanometric scale [15]. According to Figs. 6 and 8, c these catalysts formed smaller carbon deposits (see also Fig. 10B and Figures S3-D, -E, and –F), which is presumably due to the small Ni particle size at the beginning of the reaction tests. This small Ni particle size also induces the sintering of Ni as the DRM continues, thereby resulting in the irreversible deactivation of these catalysts. This is clearly observed in Fig. 14B, where the predicted deactivation curve for the m10 catalyst (which was extrapolated by regarding as a reference the time at which the change in the activity is small, which, in this case, corresponds to a ≈ 0.28) is compared with those of the solids that were studied by Sehested et al. The trends of all the curves are the same, and the curve of the m10 catalyst is almost identical to those that are observed for the solids with comparable Ni loading. Comparing the values of the deactivation constants, for the m10 catalyst, the constant is two orders of magnitude larger than that for the Ni/Zr-doped spinel. This could be regarded as a reference in studies that are being conducted under a reactive atmosphere (such as this work). It was not possible to characterize the catalysts that were used in the deactivation tests under the kinetic regime due to the small amounts that were contained in the catalytic bed. However, there is clear evidence that the stabilization of Ni against sintering when the particles are small continues to be a difficult issue to resolve. Additionally, according to the results that are presented above, the deactivation tests should be performed in the kinetic regime so that the true deactivation curve of the catalyst is observed instead of an apparent catalytic stability. 4 Conclusions The modified direct synthesis method can be used to disperse high Ni loadings in Ni-SiO2 catalysts (∼15 wt%), which is realized via the formation of Ni-phyllosilicates. These catalysts show a lower carbon deposition in short reaction times in comparison with the catalysts that were synthetized via the impregnation method (used as controls). The deactivation curves for the catalysts that were obtained with the reactor operating in the kinetic regime were fit using the deactivation model with residual activity (DMRA). For the catalysts that were synthetized via impregnation, the deactivation constant increases as the metal loading increases, thereby suggesting that the main cause of deactivation is the carbon deposition. For the Ni-SiO2 catalysts, the deactivation curves fit to the second order, and the deactivation constant decreases as metal loading increases, which is in agreement with a sintering of Ni particles during the DRM reaction, which is promoted by the presence of small Ni particles in the fresh catalysts. Thus, the initial advantage of the Ni dispersion (small Ni particles) in the inhibition of the carbon deposits was not maintained as the time on stream increased due to the Ni sintering during the DRM reaction. There is also a drawback in the use of the modified direct synthesis method: the Ni-phyllosilicates do not possess satisfactory thermal stability. Thus, the stabilization of the catalytic structure and the lowering of the sintering rate of Ni particles remain to be realized. coredata.dc:description: Nickel-containing silica catalysts (Ni-SiO2) were synthetized via two methods: i) a modified direct synthesis and ii) incipient impregnation (as a control). The catalytic activity and deactivation of the products were evaluated in the dry reforming of methane (DRM). The modified direct synthesis method was found to favour the formation of Ni-phyllosilicates; these compounds led to a high Ni dispersion in the catalysts (even with 15 wt% of Ni). At short times of reaction, these catalysts showed low carbon deposition in comparison with that of the catalysts that were synthetized via the incipient impregnation method, which produced large carbon deposits. At long times on stream, the catalysts that contained Ni-phyllosilicates showed a severe sintering of the Ni particles during the DRM reaction at 700 °C. If the reactor is not operated in the kinetic regime, the activity loss is not adequately observed, even if significant sintering of Ni has already occurred in the catalyst. With the reactor operating in the kinetic regime, the deactivation curves can be fit using the deactivation model with residual activity (DMRA), and the Ni-SiO2 catalysts followed a second-order deactivation that was caused by the Ni sintering. Finally, at short times of reaction and with the reactor operating in the kinetic regime at 700 °C, an apparent activation energy of 80.3 kJ/mole was determined for the DRM reaction.
coredata.dc:title: Deactivation of Ni-SiO2 catalysts that are synthetized via a modified direct synthesis method during the dry reforming of methane
